answers.answer: While of course I can't speak for you, is it possible that you are now more aware of your body's sensations?After my TT & subsequent calcium issues, I became obsessed with every little sensation, twitch & tingle.  After having lots of blood work & with everything finally being stable my doctor and I concluded that I am probably just more aware of sensations.  I feel that my feet fall asleep with more ease, but am I just more aware of it now?Share your concerns with your doctor, and try to relax. . .a lot of symptoms such as tingling etc. . .also manifest themselves when stressed.be well!

Thank you for your response.Actually, I would like to check whether this is a common symptom, if not, I will try to find the cause and treat it, as you may know, lack of vitamin B will cause a similar symptom! and many other causes will lead to the same symptom.  If numbness is a common symptom of a treated hypothyroidism, I won't spend much time trying to find the cause.Thank you again ..

I have had this symptom Post RAI but it is slowly 'going' as my TSH is coming down to the near 2.0 mark.I think it is just a Graves symptom along with many others that we experience on our journey to 'wellness'.Hope that eases your mind.

question: Hello,I'm 27 yrs male, and 4 yrs ago I had the graves disease, took the radio pill, became hypo.  I had been on 125 mcg synthroid, and recently changed to combination of T4, T3.Since I became hypo I started having numbness in my hands and legs, especially when I have one leg above the other for a while "less than 5 minutes" or when I sleep on my hand or anything like that.  I got a full comprehensive wellness test, and it showed that everything was perfect.  No diabetes, TSH on upper normal range "I have many symptoms when I'm on the lower normal".I'm wondering if this normal or not, I'm really worried about this symptom.Thanks a lot!
title: Is numbness Normal? Please Help :(
